metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Survey of AAHKS International Members on the Impact of COVID-19 on Hip and Knee Arthroplasty Practices Survey of AAHKS International Members on the Impact of COVID-19 on Hip and Knee Arthroplasty Practices 2 3 4 Survey of AAHKS International Members on the Impact of COVID-19 on Hip and Knee Arthroplasty Practices 2

abstract.text: 3 Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic poses an important risk to global health. This 4 study surveyed 370 international orthopaedic surgeons affiliated with the American Association 5 of Hip and Knee Surgeons to help identify the global impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on 6 patient care. A total of 99 surgeons (27% of those surveyed) completed the questionnaire 7 representing 32 different countries. Except for surgeons in Japan, all respondents noted that their 8 practice had been affected to some degree and 70% of the surgeons have cancelled elective 9 procedures. More than a third of the surgeons have had to close their practices altogether and the 10 remaining open practices were estimated to be sustainable for 7 weeks on average given their 11 current situation. The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in marked changes to the majority of 12 international arthroplasty practices.

body_text.text: In December 2019, coronavirus disease 2019 broke out in Wuhan, 15 Hubei Province, the People's Republic of China. Since that time, the disease has spread 16 worldwide to an extent not seen in decades and poses an important global health threat [1] . It is 17 now known that COVID-19 is a highly contagious disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus 18 which produces symptoms that are much more severe than the seasonal flu, with fatality rates 19 around 1.4% [2] . The virus is transmitted person-to-person and health-care professionals may 20 serve as a mechanism for hospital associated transmission and outbreaks [3] . Healthcare 21 providers are at risk of propagating this disease and this risk is not exclusive to those healthcare 22 workers at the 'front lines' of the pandemic (e.g. emergency department, isolation wards, etc.). In 23 one recent report, upwards of 78% of health-care workers infected were outside of these front 24 line areas, allowing infection to spread [4] . As such, measures to slow the spread of infection 25 have been witnessed worldwide in targeting all departments within hospitals. 26 The need to slow the rate of transmission and accountability of proper stewardship of 27 medical resources is of utmost importance. The acute spike in sick patients with COVID-19 in 28 Italy and Spain, for example, showed that hospitals could quickly become depleted of necessary 29 medical equipment to protect patients and staff. A similar situation has been seen in U.S. based 30 hospitals where we have seen key shortages in ventilators, personal protective equipment (PPE), 31 and blood products [5] [6] [7] . In response, early recommendations were made by the American The responses were anonymous and tabulated and reported in aggregate form.
Descriptive statistics including mean, standard deviation, and median values were reported for all 65 continuous variables. Percentiles and sample size were reported for categorical variables.

The survey questions are shown in Table 2 through 4. (19), or performing more administrative work (26). Ten respondents noted 79 that they were providing more non-orthopaedic patient care. Twenty-two respondents report that In general, survey results from the international hip and knee arthroplasty societies from 102 Japan, Germany, China, and Italy were similar to the results from AAHKS poll. There were 103 some notable differences between societies. Japan had the highest number of respondents still performing arthroplasty cases, while Italy had the lowest. As expected, telemedicine was adopted 105 by many societies, and most Italian surgeons are performing some form of telemedicine. We 106 were surprised to see that very few surgeons across societies practice safe intubation/extubation 107 guidelines and wear an N-95 respirator mask during operative procedures (Table 5) . COVID-19. Thus, they recommend routine wear of the respirator at all times to prevent infection and spread both in the OR and while rounding on the floor. In our study, it was found that 67 151 surgeons reported using an N-95 respirator to some capacity in the OR, with 32 wearing them in 152 the OR for every surgical procedure. However, over half of responders (58) reported not using an 153 N-95 mask during any inpatient rounding duties. Based on the data available from the Wuhan 154 study, it would seem reasonable to recommend using an N-95 respirator mask at all times; 155 limited access to N-95 respirators may have played a role in the reported numbers in our survey.

Perhaps the most alarming finding of our study was that more than one third of 157 international arthroplasty surgeons (37/99) have been forced to close their practice altogether. Department of Health and Human Services have also announced relaxation of HIPAA requirements and provided waivers for the use of telemedicine during the pandemic in order to 174 ensure care for COVID-19 and non-COVID patients is continued [15] . As gleaned from the 175 survey, a number of international members are using some form of telemedicine to communicate 176 with patients. Maintaining contact with our patients is of paramount importance during this 177 crisis, as practices will need to be reinvigorated once the pandemic resolves.

In our study, 44 respondents have had their wages stopped to limit costs and support 191 This study has several limitations mainly due to its survey design. First, it is possible that 192 the population who chose to complete the survey represents a small subset of the orthopaedic 193 arthroplasty community and is not indicative of the larger group as a whole. However, given the 194 large cohort of arthroplasty surgeons encompassed in the AAHKS this may not be accurate.

Another limitation is the overall response rate of 27%, which raises the potential for non-responder bias. However, we extended the survey to include additional individuals from different 197 arthroplasty societies and these results were found to be generally similar. Perhaps those that are 198 continuing their practices did not have time to respond, falsely skewing the data collected.

FIGREF0.text: Materials and Methods: A web-based survey was developed by the American Association of47 Hip and Knee Surgeons (AAHKS) and administered using SurveyMonkey (SurveyMonkey, San 48 Mateo, CA), a survey platform for online data collection and analysis. The survey consisted of a 49 series of questions related to the COVID-19 pandemic and its effects on joint arthroplasty 50practice. The survey was sent to all international AAHKS members on April 8, 2020 and closed 51 5 days later to allow for preparation and submission of this paper to the journal supplement. A 52 similar survey had also been sent to AAHKS members within the U.S. and Canada and those 53 results were used to communicate the degree of practice disruptions to the federal government.

FIGREF1.text: Three hundred and seventy international members were sent the email and 99 members55 (27%) completed the survey within the five-day open window. Thirty-two different countries 56 were represented in the responses and are listed in Table 1. The survey was translated to Chinese, 57 Japanese, Italian, and German and additionally distributed to members of the hip and knee 58 societies in these countries in order to garner more precise information from surgeons practicing 59 in countries affected in one way or another by COVID-19. Two-hundered and sixty additional surgeons from the Japanese Society of Replacement Arthroplasty (JSRA), the German 61 Orthopedic Society, the Chinese Orthopedic Association (COA) and the Italian Hip Society 62 (SIA) responded to the translated survey.

FIGREF3.text: Of the 370 active international AAHKS members sent the request, 99 respondents 68 (27%) satisfactorily completed the survey. The survey responses are distributed through Tables 2 69 to 4. For simplicity, as the number of respondents was 99, percentages were omitted as the 70 recorded responses roughly equal the percentage. 71 Respondents were greatly impacted by the effects of COVID-19 on their patient practice, 72 with only 3 respondents from Japan indicating no changes to their arthroplasty practice at their 73 respective hospitals. The majority of respondents stated that their practice has been affected, 74 with 71 confirming their hospital had stopped elective inpatient surgery altogether. Some noted 75 that their hospitals cancelled all types of surgeries in response to COVID-19 pandemic (14 76 responses from countries including Mexico, India, Italy, Chile, Uruguay, United Kingdom, 77 Philippines, Spain, South Africa, and France). Many surgeons noted a shift in their focus to non-78 surgical clinical care

FIGREF4.text: 80 their respective hospitals have been unable to care for all COVID-19 infected patients and a large 81 number have encountered disruptions in both supply and staffing needs. Because of the COVID-82 19 pandemic, an average of 81 cases were estimated to be deferred per respondent, with the 83 maximum response of 2,000 estimated cases. 84 The arthroplasty-related procedures still being performed at most hospitals were most 85 commonly semi-urgent arthroplasty problems including periprosthetic fracture, massively failed 86 total joint arthroplasty, and 1 st stage resection for prosthetic joint infection, demonstrating that 87 semi-urgent procedures were still performed at many hospitals. Of the cases that were still 88 performed, about half (48 responses) replied that there was some form of preoperative testing for 89 COVID-19 infection. Most surgeons used an N-95 respirator to some capacity while operating 90 (67), but to a lesser extent when rounding on the wards (41). 91 Surgeons were affected personally. There were 4 surgeons that tested positive for 92 COVID-19 infection. Almost half (42) of the surgeons reported they were no longer working at 93 all. Responders reported that the average number of weeks their practices could sustain the 94 current economic pressures was approximately 7 weeks. Forty-four respondents replied that they 95 have had to forego their salary and 22 have had to lay-off or furlough employees. A large 96 majority (82) of responders have not received any financial assistance from the government. 97 Many surgeons have turned to digital platforms to aid in their direct patient care with 72 98 relying on telephone or video based applications to communicate with patients. WhatsApp 99 (WhatsApp, Menlo Park, CA) seems to be a preferred method of patient communication for 100 responders.

FIGREF6.text: COVID-19 has progressed to a pandemic posing a substantial global health threat 109[1][2][3][4]. Global, regional, and local pressures have affected orthopaedic surgeons worldwide. This110 survey of international AAHKS members is an attempt to characterize the impacts of the 111 COVID-19 pandemic on arthroplasty practices worldwide. Most notably, the majority of 112 arthroplasty practices have been affected with all 99 surgeons responding that their practice has 113 been affected to some degree and 71 having cancelled elective procedures altogether. Semi-114 urgent procedures, such as those performed for periprosthetic fractures or infections, are still 115 being performed. More than a third of responders noted that they have had to close their 116 practices altogether and the remaining open practices were estimated to be sustainable for 117 another 7 weeks on average. 118 The financial impact of COVID-19 on arthroplasty practices worldwide is 119 unprecedented. The American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons and AAHKS have requested 120 from the U.S. government a number of provisions to support arthroplasty surgeons during this 121 healthcare and economic crisis. These include flexibility with Health Insurance Portability and 122 Accountability Act (HIPAA) rulings for good faith actions to provide telehealth, a delay of the 123 2019 Merit-Based Incentive Payment System reporting deadline, Good Samaritan protections for 124 COVID-19 volunteers, Federal support for physician practices, suspension of any possible 125 proposed Medicare cuts, and an allowance to expand of physician owned hospitals to treat 126 Key shortages in ventilators, personal protective equipment, and blood products have 128 been observed throughout the U.S. [5-7]. As more local governments have issued 'shelter in 129 place' laws, blood donations have decreased only adding to the shortage. In an attempt to slow 130 the depletion of these vital resources, many hospitals have cancelled elective surgeries including 131 THA and TKA. Our results suggest that this trend is occurring internationally as well, with 71 132 practices having cancelled all elective procedures. Sixty-four international surgeons responded 133 that their hospital is experiencing supply disruptions, 41% experiencing staff related disruptions, 134 and 22% will be unable to take care of all infected COVID patients requiring hospitalization. 135 Anesthesia providers are at a particular risk, as every intubation and extubation poses an 136 aerosol-producing chance to spread the infection [10]. Interestingly, less than half of the 137 respondents claim that protocols have been implemented to decrease the risk of infection to 138 hospital staff after intubation and extubation. Close to half of the respondents endorsed efforts to 139 screen surgical patients for the SARS-CoV-2 virus in an attempt to improve overall safety for all 140 providers. Ultimately, limiting surgical procedures decreases the amount of necessary PPE and 141 as such there appears to be international pressure to decrease amount of elective procedures. 142 While only 4 respondents have tested positive for COVID-19, ten percent of surgeons are 143 currently performing non-orthopaedic medical care and may be at further risk of contracting the 144 virus. A survey of orthopaedic surgeons in Wuhan, China was recently published examining the 145 effects of utilizing N-95 respirators on COVID transmission [11]. The authors determined that 146 the incidence of infection in orthopaedic surgeons was up to 20.7% in the early stages of the 147 outbreak with the main suspected site of infection occurring on the general wards (i.e. not 148 isolation wards). The use of N-95 respirators was found to have a protective effect against 149

FIGREF7.text: Twenty-two have had to layoff or furlough employees due to economic burdens and the average 159 time practices were estimated to remain open given their current economic scenario was 7.3 160 weeks. In the U.S., elective procedures account for 48% of hospital costs and potentially an even 161 larger percentage of revenues [12]. Additionally, five musculoskeletal procedures (hip 162 arthroplasty, knee arthroplasty, laminectomy, spinal fusion, and lower extremity fracture care) 163 account for 17% of those elective procedures. Without elective procedures continuing to provide 164 revenue, the financial burden on hospital organizations will only increase. In the U.S., President 165 Donald Trump signed the bipartisan Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) 166 Act on March 27th, 2020. This $2 trillion relief fund is aimed at aiding individuals, businesses, 167 and state/local governments [13]. The CARES Act provides $100 billion in relief funds to 168 hospitals and healthcare providers, including $30 billion in payment, not loans, that was 169 immediately released to any healthcare provider who billed Medicare in 2019, based on a 170 formula related to their fee-for-service charges [14]. Orthopaedic practices with less than 500 171 employees are eligible for loan programs through the Small Business Administration. The US 172

FIGREF8.text: 179 hospital funding. Additionally, 19 endorsed undergoing personal financial stress, but only 8 180 responded having received some financial support from their government. Fortunately, 9 181 respondents endorsed receiving some private financial help either from private loans or their own 182 institution. The vast majority of surgeons (82) reported no financial aid at all. Members of the 183 AAHKS international committee were contacted to discuss the availability of federal aid from 184 their countries. Surgeons from the United Kingdom, Chile, Colombia, New Zealand, Italy, Japan 185 or France have not received any help from their federal governments. Several countries have had 186 some actions towards decreasing taxes or debt relief, or assistance in the public sector, but the 187 resources available are quite limited and usually are not available for surgeons in private 188 practice. In the midst of this global pandemic, the full economic repercussions are unclear; 189 however, surgeons receiving direct aid from international governments remains relatively 190 uncommon at this time.

FIGREF9.text: This survey based study of international members of the American 200 Association of Hip and Knee Surgeons demonstrates the global impacts of COVID-19. The 201 COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in marked changes to the majority of international practices, 202 with 71% of responders noting cancellation of elective procedures at their respective hospitals 203 and 37% members reporting closure of their practice.

TABREF0.text: College of Surgeons to delay elective surgical procedures in an effort to save PPE and minimize these shortages[8]. A large majority of U.S. hospitals have since cancelled elective surgeries for the immediate future. It is unclear whether similar strategies were taken by governments worldwide, as this would depend on the volume of COVID-19 infected cases in any specific country.Total hip (THA) and knee arthroplasty (TKA) are some of the highest volume procedures performed in hospitals on an elective basis[9]. Furthermore, there are certain procedures involving THA or TKA that may require more urgent treatment, such as those patients presenting with periprosthetic joint infections or fractures. Some of these patients could be COVID-19 infected and require a surgical intervention in an emergent or semi-urgent basis.Orthopaedic surgeons worldwide are attempting to balance minimizing COVID-19 disease burden while still providing necessary care. To date, it is unknown how arthroplasty surgeons worldwide are altering their practice in the setting of COVID-19. The purpose of this survey was to determine the impact of COVID-19 on arthroplasty practices internationally.
